it's kind of under the radar
chairman Jerome Powell he delivered an
important message that went largely

message he's telling us that he intends
to pop the bubbles both asset price and
credit bubbles now he didn't communicate
a precise threshold for bubble popping
but I believe he meant not just big
bubbles but potentially little bubbles
and possibly even pre bubbles if they
become necessary to contain the risks of

had in the past all different Fed
Chairman and if we go back in time
it was Janet Yellen Ben Bernanke and
Alan Greenspan and in their speeches
that they gave or when they had these
meetings they never talked about
financial excess and it's very
interesting book because Powell actually
mentioned this he went on to say we are
aware that raising rates too slowly
might raise the risk that monetary
policy would need to tighten abruptly
down the road in response to an
unexpectedly sharp increase in inflation
or financial excesses jeopardizing the
economic expansion now the language in
this sentence might seem ordinary if
read very quickly
but comparisons to what we would have
heard from Yellen show it was a clear
departure so Powell's opening statement
wasn't just boilerplate language those
three words or financial excesses never
appeared in the same context in any of

in the opening statement here's the UH
next excerpt this one is in response to
a question about wage growth our role
though is also to you know to make sure
that the maximum employment happens in a

the feds role in the same way
she never elevated financial stability

answering a question about wage growth
there was no prompting whatsoever
the next questionnaire asked about
inflation overshooting the feds target
and here's Powell's response to this
we're going ahead and moving gradually
and trying to navigate between two risks
really one would be moving too quickly
inflation never gets back to target if
we do that and the other is moving too
slowly and then we have we have too much
inflation or financial instability and
we have to raise quickly and that can
also have bad outcomes
once again Powell cited financial risks
as a potential trigger for monetary

what he's saying here is that he's
